items.synopsis: Australian law enforcement has started solving missing persons and unidentified remains cases using official police access to private genealogy databases, which combined, hold the DNA records of millions of people around the world.

items.synopsis: The risk of developing shingles increases with age. From next month a new vaccine against the virus, tipped to be 90 per cent effective, will be available through the National Immunisation Program for older and immunocompromised Australians.

title.children: Federal government makes new shingles vaccine free for older Australians from November 1

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Earlier this morning a meeting of the full UN Security Council began in New York. We've been told it is unlikely to issue a statement, but we will bring you as many updates as we are able to obtain. Ahead of the meeting, we heard from both the Israeli and the Palestinian ambassadors to the UN. Israeli UN ambassador Gilad Erdan said: "These are war crimes, blatant documented war crimes. The era of reasoning with these savages is over. Now is the time to obliterate Hamas terror infrastructure, to completely erase it, so that such horrors are never committed again." Palestinian UN ambassador Riyad Mansour said: "Israel keeps saying: The blockade and repeated assaults on Gaza are to destroy Hamas military capabilities and ensure security. ... Its blockade and assaults accomplished neither. When Israel now tries to justify yet another assault by the same faulty premise, no one should say or do anything to encourage it down this path."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: The UN Security Council has been meeting in New York

children.content: Israel’s Ambassador to the United Nations Gilad Erdan speaks during a meeting of the United Nations Security Council
(Reuters: Mike Segar)
Earlier this morning a meeting of the full UN Security Council began in New York. We've been told it is unlikely to issue a statement, but we will bring you as many updates as we are able to obtain.
Ahead of the meeting, we heard from both the Israeli and the Palestinian ambassadors to the UN.
Israeli UN ambassador Gilad Erdan said:

"These are war crimes, blatant documented war crimes. The era of reasoning with these savages is over. Now is the time to obliterate Hamas terror infrastructure, to completely erase it, so that such horrors are never committed again."
Palestinian UN ambassador Riyad Mansour said:

"Israel keeps saying: The blockade and repeated assaults on Gaza are to destroy Hamas military capabilities and ensure security. ... Its blockade and assaults accomplished neither. When Israel now tries to justify yet another assault by the same faulty premise, no one should say or do anything to encourage it down this path."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: North America correspondent Carrington Clarke has been across reactions in the US. He said the message from Washington was that although the US did not currently have evidence that the attack by Hamas on Israel was directed by any other foreign agent or was in concert with them, "they are concerned that part of the motivation might have been to try to thwart the attempts, as they put it, to normalise relations between Israel and particularly with some of its Arab neighbours". Here US Secretary of State Antony Blinken speaks on the issue: "It's no surprise that those opposed to the efforts to normalise relations between Saudi Arabia and Israel, and more broadly, to normalise Israel's relations with countries throughout the region and beyond, who opposes it? Hezbollah, Hamas and Iran. "So to the extent that this was designed to try and derail the efforts that were being made, that speaks volumes. "But right now, the focus is on dealing with this attack, dealing with Hamas and we'll come to the normalisation efforts — which, by the way, are very difficult when it comes to Saudi Arabia and Israel." Watch the full update from the US here:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: US secretary of state speaks on possible motivation for attack

children.content: North America correspondent Carrington Clarke has been across reactions in the US.

He said the message from Washington was that although the US did not currently have evidence that the attack by Hamas on Israel was directed by any other foreign agent or was in concert with them, "they are concerned that part of the motivation might have been to try to thwart the attempts, as they put it, to normalise relations between Israel and particularly with some of its Arab neighbours".
Here
US Secretary of State Antony Blinken
speaks on the issue:

"It's no surprise that those opposed to the efforts to normalise relations between Saudi Arabia and Israel, and more broadly, to normalise Israel's relations with countries throughout the region and beyond, who opposes it? Hezbollah, Hamas and Iran.
"So to the extent that this was designed to try and derail the efforts that were being made, that speaks volumes.

"But right now, the focus is on dealing with this attack, dealing with Hamas and we'll come to the normalisation efforts — which, by the way, are very difficult when it comes to Saudi Arabia and Israel."
Watch the full update from the US here:

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Good morning everyone. I'm Emily Clark from ABC News International and I'll be helping to bring you updates on this story today. On the ground in Israel, the military says it has now regained control of most infiltration points along the Gaza border that were breached during the attack. Israel says it has deployed thousands of soldiers to the southern region around Gaza and was evacuating citizens from the area. Of course the country's military has a lot of questions to answer in terms of how this attack could happen. From the southern town of Ofakim that was attacked by Hamas, Defence Minister Yoav Gallant said: "The price the Gaza Strip will pay will be a very heavy one that will change reality for generations."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Israel evacuates citizens from the south, fortifies border

children.content: Good morning everyone. I'm Emily Clark from ABC News International and I'll be helping to bring you updates on this story today.
On the ground in Israel, the military says it has now regained control of most infiltration points along the Gaza border that were breached during the attack.
Israel says it has deployed thousands of soldiers to the southern region around Gaza and was evacuating citizens from the area.
Of course the country's military has a lot of questions to answer in terms of how this attack could happen.
From the southern town of Ofakim that was attacked by Hamas, Defence Minister Yoav Gallant said: "The price the Gaza Strip will pay will be a very heavy one that will change reality for generations."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Parent company of IGA, Metcash, says the CEO of its liquor branch, Chris Baddock, has retired from the role for health reasons. In a short statement uploaded to the ASX earlier this morning, Metcash says John Barakat will take over the role in the interim while the company searches for a successor. Metcash CEO Doug Jones thanked Mr Baddock for his "significant contribution" in growing the company's liquor pillar, and said he would take up a part-time advisory role with Metcash after a four-month break to assist with the growth of the liquor division.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Metcash Liquor CEO retires from role for health reasons

children.content: Parent company of IGA, Metcash, says the CEO of its liquor branch, Chris Baddock, has retired from the role for health reasons.
In a short statement uploaded to the ASX earlier this morning, Metcash says John Barakat will take over the role in the interim while the company searches for a successor.

Metcash CEO Doug Jones thanked Mr Baddock for his "significant contribution" in growing the company's liquor pillar, and said he would take up a part-time advisory role with Metcash after a four-month break to assist with the growth of the liquor division.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: With Peter Costello stepping down from the Future Fund next February, Treasurer Jim Chalmers is now tasked with appointing a new chair. Mr Chalmers has thanked Mr Costello for his "significant contribution" with the fund, and a formal merit-based recruitment process will get underway to find a replacement chair. You can hear more from our senior business correspondent Peter Ryan below:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 'Merit-based' recruitment process underway for Future Fund chair replacement

children.content: With Peter Costello stepping down from the Future Fund next February, Treasurer Jim Chalmers is now tasked with appointing a new chair.
Mr Chalmers has thanked Mr Costello for his "significant contribution" with the fund, and a formal merit-based recruitment process will get underway to find a replacement chair.
You can hear more from our
senior business correspondent Peter Ryan
below:

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Former Liberal treasurer Peter Costello won't be seeking a third term as chairman of the federal government's Future Fund. A spokesman for Treasurer Jim Chalmers has confirmed Mr Costello's stint, first as a board member, then as chair, will end in February after 14 years. Mr Costello's decision to step down follows renewal at top institutions including the Reserve Bank and the Productivity Commission. The spokesman thanked Mr Costello for "his significant contribution" and said a merit-based recruitment process will now commence to appoint a new Chair. Mr Costello established the sovereign wealth fund as John Howard's treasurer in 2006 with $60 billion of budget surpluses and part of the proceeds from the Telstra privatisation.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Peter Costello stepping down as chair of Future Fund

children.content: Former Liberal treasurer

Reserve Bank
and the
Productivity Commission
The spokesman thanked Mr Costello for "his significant contribution" and said a merit-based recruitment process will now commence to appoint a new Chair.
Mr Costello established the sovereign wealth fund as John Howard's treasurer in 2006 with $60 billion of budget surpluses and part of the proceeds from the Telstra privatisation.
